title: Otto Stowe
text:
Otto Stowe (born February 25, 1949 in <a href="Chicago">Chicago</a>, <a href="Illinois">Illinois</a>) is a former <a href="American%20football">American football</a> <a href="wide%20receiver">wide receiver</a> who played four seasons in the <a href="National%20Football%20League">NFL</a> for the <a href="Denver%20Broncos">Denver Broncos</a>, <a href="Dallas%20Cowboys">Dallas Cowboys</a>, and <a href="Miami%20Dolphins">Miami Dolphins</a>. He played <a href="college%20football">college football</a> at <a href="Iowa%20State%20University">Iowa State University</a>.
Early years.
At <a href="Springfield%20Southeast%20High%20School">Feitshans High School</a> he was an All-state selection in both <a href="American%20football">football</a> and <a href="basketball">basketball</a>. He went on to play <a href="basketball">basketball</a> at <a href="Iowa%20State%20University">Iowa State University</a>, before focusing on <a href="American%20football">football</a> after his sophomore season and proceeding to lead the team in receiving for 3 consecutive years. He began as a <a href="defensive%20back">defensive back</a> before being switched to <a href="wide%20receiver">wide receiver</a>.
As a senior in 1970, he had the most prolific receiving season in school history up to that point, breaking single-season school records in receptions (59), receiving yards (822) and <a href="touchdown">touchdown</a>s (6). He also led the <a href="Big%20Eight%20Conference">Big Eight</a> in all three categories and ranked 13th nationally in receiving, earning first-team all-<a href="Big%20Eight%20Conference">Big Eight</a> honors. His 59 catches ranks fifth all-time and his 822 receiving yards seventh all-time in school history for a season. He finished his career as <a href="Iowa%20State%20University">Iowa State University</a> all-time leader in receptions (132) and receiving yards (1,751), and second in career <a href="touchdown">touchdown</a>s (10). He still ranks third in career receptions and fifth in receiving yards.
In 2008, he was inducted into the <a href="Iowa%20State%20University">Iowa State University</a> Athletics Hall of Fame.
Professional career.
Miami Dolphins.
Stowe was selected by the <a href="Miami%20Dolphins">Miami Dolphins</a> in the second round (47th overall) of the <a href="1971%20NFL%20Draft">1971 NFL Draft</a>. As a rookie, he was the backup to <a href="Paul%20Warfield">Paul Warfield</a>, catching 5 passes for 68 yards and 1 <a href="touchdown">touchdown</a>. He again saw limited action in his second season, with 13 receptions, 276 yards and 2 <a href="touchdown">touchdown</a>s). Six of the receptions for 140 yards and both touchdowns came in a single "<a href="Monday%20Night%20Football">Monday Night Football</a>" game against the <a href="Arizona%20Cardinals">St. Louis Cardinals</a> while replacing an injured Warfield. Despite winning a <a href="Super%20Bowl">Super Bowl</a>, he requested to be traded after the season.
On May 10, <a href="1973%20NFL%20season">1973</a>, he was traded to the <a href="Dallas%20Cowboys">Dallas Cowboys</a> in exchange for wide receiver <a href="Ron%20Sellers">Ron Sellers</a> and a second round draft choice (#47-<a href="Benny%20Malone">Benny Malone</a>). He played on two <a href="Super%20Bowl">Super Bowl</a> teams, including the undefeated <a href="1972%20Miami%20Dolphins%20season">1972 Miami Dolphins</a>.
Dallas Cowboys.
In <a href="1973%20NFL%20season">1973</a>, he was having a <a href="Pro%20Bowl">Pro Bowl</a> type season starting opposite to <a href="Bob%20Hayes">Bob Hayes</a>, but suffered a broken ankle in the seventh game against the <a href="Philadelphia%20Eagles">Philadelphia Eagles</a>, that placed him on the <a href="injured%20reserve%20list">injured reserve list</a> and would hamper him for the rest of his career. He was replaced with rookie <a href="Drew%20Pearson%20%28American%20football%29">Drew Pearson</a> for the rest of the season, but still led the team with 6 <a href="touchdown">touchdown</a> receptions and was second in receiving with 389 yards.
Even though he was starting for the Cowboys, he wasn't happy with his contract, so he was traded to the <a href="Denver%20Broncos">Denver Broncos</a> for a third round draft choice (#75-<a href="John%20Smith%20%28running%20back%29">John Smith</a>) on September 5, <a href="1974%20NFL%20season">1974</a>.
Denver Broncos.
In <a href="1974%20NFL%20season">1974</a>, he had a disappointing season after not being fully recovered from his previous injury which limited his mobility. He appeared in 8 games, while registering 2 receptions for 9 yards and one touchdown. On May 6, <a href="1975%20NFL%20season">1975</a>, he was traded along with a sixth round draft choice (#156-<a href="Art%20Best">Art Best</a>) to the <a href="Los%20Angeles%20Rams">Los Angeles Rams</a>, as compensation for signing <a href="free%20agent">free agent</a> <a href="Phil%20Olsen%20%28American%20football%29">Phil Olsen</a>.
Los Angeles Rams.
On August 18, Stowe informed the <a href="Los%20Angeles%20Rams">Los Angeles Rams</a> of his decision to retire before the start of the <a href="1975%20NFL%20season">1975 season</a>. He finished his career after only four seasons, registering 43 receptions, 742 yards, and 10 <a href="touchdown">touchdown</a>s.
Personal life.
In 1976, he was a college football graduate assistant at <a href="Washington%20State%20University">Washington State University</a>. The next year, he became the wide receivers coach at the <a href="University%20of%20Pittsburgh">University of Pittsburgh</a>.
